awd_titl_txt: MRI:  Acquisition of a Liquid Chromatography-Mass Spectrometry (LC-MS) System to Enable Research and Enhance Undergraduate Education at Western Washington University
awd_abstract_narration:
An award is made to Western Washington University (WWU) for the acquisition of a state-of-the-art liquid chromatography-mass spectrometry (LC-MS) system. This instrument, which will be housed and maintained within a centralized instrument facility, will provide a core institutional resource for a broad range of research and teaching activities at WWU's main campus and Shannon Point Marine Center (SPMC). As a primarily undergraduate institution, WWU is committed to providing the highest-level of classroom instruction, while also offering authentic research experiences for undergraduate and masters-level graduate students. The LC-MS will directly support this mission. First, it will be incorporated into multiple courses in the STEM curriculum, providing meaningful exposure to mass spectrometry for hundreds of undergraduates every year. The LC-MS will also become a key component of a collaborative project involving laboratory courses at WWU and a local community college. Finally, outside of the classroom, students involved in faculty led research will be afforded new opportunities for hands-on training in modern mass spectrometry techniques, providing them with a skill set that will be valuable when seeking employment in the scientific workforce or for pursuing advanced graduate studies.

In addition to impacts on teaching and student training, the LC-MS will be transformative for numerous research programs at WWU and SPMC. Mass spectrometry is a foundational technique in the biological and chemical sciences, and is often the preferred method for confirming molecular structure or for measuring the abundance of specific compounds in complex biological and environmental samples. Examples of research efforts that will be enabled by the LC-MS include the engineering of proteins with unique biological properties, structural studies of proteins involved in blood coagulation or the maintenance of cell shape, identification and quantitation of signaling molecules and other natural products that are involved in ecological interactions and responses to environmental change, fundamental investigations of protein and gene regulation systems, and the synthesis of novel compounds. In all cases, the results of these studies will be disseminated to the broader scientific community at appropriate scientific conferences and through peer-reviewed publications.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Modern liquid chromatography mass spectrometry (LC-MS) is a foundational technique in the chemical and biological sciences that facilitates the confirmation of molecular structure and the sensitive detection of substances in complex mixtures. With funds from this NSF Major Research Instrumentation award, Western Washington University (WWU) has acquired a state-of-the-art LC-MS system consisting of an Agilent 6545XT AdvanceBio quadrupole time-of-flight (Q-TOF) mass spectrometer equipped with an electrospray source and interfaced with an Agilent 1290/1260 HPLC. This instrument is housed and maintained within WWU's University Instrument Center, which is a shared instrumentation facility that provides access and expertise to users across WWU's multiple campuses. Since its installation, the LC-MS has seen increasing use supporting faculty and student research at WWU in fields such as biochemistry, environmental science, organic chemistry, materials science, and others. Over the lifetime of this award, a total of 14 different WWU investigators have utilized this instrumentation. Examples of specific applications include monitoring of enzymatic ligation reactions, verifying the identity of recombinant proteins and associated mutants, quantifying small molecule release from anthropogenic nanomaterials, and characterization of synthetic small molecules and peptides. Notably, the diversity of projects supported by the LC-MS has spurred the creation of a dedicated mass spectrometry user group in which faculty, students, and instrument support specialists meet regularly throughout the academic year to share research, technical tips, and best practices for use of the Q-TOF system.

In addition to supporting research, the LC-MS system has led to broader impacts in two significant ways. First, the instrument has provided a new opportunity for training undergraduate and masters students in the techniques of modern mass spectrometry. In total, 23 students from WWU Chemistry, Environmental Science, and Behavioral Neuroscience have gained hands-on experience in the use of the LC-MS and associated data analysis software, which is a valuable skillset for students seeking employment or admission to graduate programs after graduation. Second, the LC-MS has been incorporated into multiple courses in the WWU STEM curriculum. A total of 7 unique classes offered by the departments of chemistry and environmental science have utilized the instrument for instruction in the areas of general chemistry, organic chemistry, biochemistry, instrumental analysis, environmental toxicology, watershed biogeochemistry, and biostatistical analysis. In these classes, the LC-MS is used for instrument demonstrations and analysis of student samples, thereby introducing numerous students to techniques in mass spectrometry as part of their undergraduate coursework.

 


Last Modified: 01/30/2023
Modified by: John Antos
